body: There are some intrinsic functions missing and/or interface stubs (`Function 'dsqrt' not found or not implemented yet (if it is intrinsic)`) -- apart from that: `IF(...) CALL ...` and the `EXTERNAL` attribute.

issue.title: Tracking netlib
issue.body: We should track progress on how well the libraries on [netlib](https://netlib.org/) can be compiled. Parsing, yes, but actually emitting code / performance comparisons should be looked at regularly.

body: With `--allow-implicit-interface --implicit-typing`, current `main` generates (unverified) ASR for all files in `scipy/optimize/minpack`

I am going to setup CI tests to compile these codes, for now to ASR, so that we don't have regressions.

* SciPy: AST
* MinPack: ASR
* stdlib: ASR

I created a dedicated issue for this: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/858

```
semantic error: Attribute declaration not supported
  --> /home/pranavchiku/scipy/scipy/optimize/minpack/dpmpar.f:39:7
   |
39 |       equivalence (dmach(1),mcheps(1))
   |       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 
   ```

@Pranavchiku Thanks -- that's good, that's probably something that didn't pop up before. I think now that `EQUIVALENCE` gets introduced with new ASR nodes we can implement this fully.


edit: I'm sorry @Pranavchiku -- somehow I edited your comment instead of responding! Sorry!
@Pranavchiku I'm sorry about this unintended edit -- would you mind posting the error log again?
Yeah no worries, I will do that :)

Minimal reproducible example
```
      recursive
     *double precision function dpmpar(i)
      integer mcheps(4)
      double precision dmach(3)
      equivalence (dmach(1),mcheps(1))
      end
```
Yes, just open up a new issue for equivalence. That's a known missing feature.

issue.title: Setup automatic formatting
issue.body:
After we can

* [ ]  #512 

And possibly compile more of SciPy (we'll decide on the current momentum), let's enable automatic formatting of the code using https://pre-commit.ci/. See also:

* https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/36#issuecomment-1273661608

Let's not do it right now, to keep the barrier of entry low, so that we can focus on delivering "beta" of LFortran.

The above setup should be quite smooth, we will simply squash PRs from contributor that do not format their code. In order to avoid the formatting commits for larger PRs, we will need to format locally, which raises the barrier a little bit, but I think it will not be a big deal once LFortran is in beta. Right now let's focus on getting into beta.

issue.title: Experiences with LFortran
issue.body:
*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/574

The code for the [demo](https://gitlab.com/lfortran/examples/mvp_demo/-/tree/master/src) uses arrays. With LFortran on WSL 2, I can run a small program interactively such as 


```
integer :: i
i = 3
print*,i,i**2
```

but I can't use arrays. When run interactively the program


```
integer :: ivec(1)
ivec(1)  = 3
```
gives a segmentation fault.

However, if I store

```
program main
integer :: ivec(1)
ivec(1) = 3
print*,ivec
end program main
```
in `vec.f90` I can compile it with `lfortran vec.f90` and run it.

LFortran does not recognize the one-line program `end`. 

`lfortran end.f90`

gives

`input:1:1 semantic error: Variable 'end' not declared`

issue.title: Parsing SciPy TODO list

labels.name: SciPy
labels.description: issues related to enable LFortran to compile the entire FORTRAN codebase in SciPy

issue.body:
The following `lfortran --show-ast --fixed-form $file > $file.ast` now works for every `*.f` file in SciPy, except the following three issues:

* [x] include statements (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/777)
* [x] data in body (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/778)
* [x] else syntax (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/779)

After resolving those three issues, here is a TODO list:

* [x] Get formatting working for all files: `lfortran --fixed-form fmt --no-color $file > $file.f90`
    * [x]  https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/782
* [x] Use gfortran to compile the `.f90` files generated in the previous step instead of the original `.f` files.
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/781
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/784
    * [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/785
* [x] Link everything with SciPy (still use f2py with the original `.f` files) and ensure everything builds
* [ ] Ensure all tests pass if we build all`.f` files via LFortran -> GFortran
* [ ] I also want to check that the f90 can be parsed with LFortran

This would be a very solid test that we have parsed everything correctly to AST (and can format everything correctly); everything that is tested by SciPy tests at least.

issue.title: Data statement bugfix
issue.body: While checking the files in `scipy/special/amos/` etc in #869 I fell on an error, and I think `current_body` is sometimes not allocated. For this I entered a simple check. However, the issue seems not too hard to surmount: The data assignment statements that throw errors are assignments to existing 1d array items with n elements. @Smit-create

body:
As of now (after PRs are merged) we got very far, all ASR works and the `.f90` compiles to LLVM, but the rest of the files do not get compiled in, because we do not generate code. That is enabled by:
```diff
diff --git a/src/CMakeLists.txt b/src/CMakeLists.txt
index 3cc9cfc..1e80573 100644
--- a/src/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/src/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ if (CMAKE_Fortran_COMPILER_ID STREQUAL "GNU")
         "-std=legacy;-Wno-implicit-interface;-Wno-unused-dummy-argument;-Wno-compare-reals;-Wno-do-subscript")
 else()
     set_source_files_properties(${SRC_F77} PROPERTIES COMPILE_OPTIONS
-        "--no-warnings;--fixed-form;--implicit-typing;--allow-implicit-interface")
+        "--generate-object-code;--no-warnings;--fixed-form;--implicit-typing;--allow-implicit-interface")
 endif()
 add_library(minpack ${SRC})
 install(TARGETS minpack
```
